Gordon Calls for End of'Compulsory Students'
President Lincoln Gordon told a University of Hawaii audience Wednesday
that "higher education seems to be moving from a privilege to a right to an obligation for every young man or woman."
Dr. Gordon, in Hawaii as part of a
Western fund raising tour, delivered the
speech at the inauguration of Harlan
Cleveland as president of the University
of Hawaii at Honolulu.
He called for the abolition of "compulsory studenthood" in the nation's
colleges and universities, and criticized "the lockstep tradition which determines the timing of higher education
in the life of the young adult, and the
false credentialism which limits employment opportunities for those not
yet feeling an inner urge for further
formal education."
National Service
As an "ideal" remedy, the President
suggested "an open system of ordinary
employment, backed by a governmentally
financed system of universal opportunity
for national service."
"That such service," he said, "could
be made responsive to the crying needs
of urban, environmental and international development seems to me self-evident."
He suggested the need for a strong
national commitment "to equality of
opportunity" in higher education, and
commended the Carnegie Commission
plan to provide "sufficient financial aid

by 1976 to remove all economic barriers" and correct "curricular and policy inequities creating special barriers
for black students and other disadvantaged ethnic groups."
The President pointed to draft and
employment practices which put pressure on young people to go directly
from high school to college and remain
there, and said that "significant numbers" of these "students" are restless
and rebellious, wondering why they are
really" in school. "Instead of joy in
learning," he stated, "this group feels

Students, Faculty Asked
To Meet on Governance
Citing a need to create "an atmosphere of trust" between faculty and
students, the Student Council has called for a meeting of the SC and the faculty on the governance issue.
In a letter sent to all faculty members, the SC claimed that "university
governance at the Jonns Hopkins University must be a joint effort of the students and the faculty." This joint effort,
the letter implied, was being hampered
by a lack of understanding and cornmunication between students and faculty. The SC hopes to help remedy
this lack through the student-faculty
meeting, planned for today at four o'clock in Levering Hall.
John Guess, President of the Student
Council, views the meeting as a forum
where both students and faculty will
be able to present their opinions on the
governance
issue
and "hopefully,
bridge the communication gap."
Another goal of the meeting, suggested Guess, would be to ease what he feels
Is an attitude of mutual student-faculty
mistrust. Guess stated that this mistrust would have to end before students
and faculty could work together on the
governance issue. "If there can't be any
trust now, there won't be any trust
later," he commented.
Concrete Action
Guess indicated that he would also
like to see some concrete action resulting from the meeting. He and the
SC want the Faculty General Assembly
to issue a new charge to the present ad
hoc Committee on Governance, directing it to study and recommend procedures to deal with the present dissatisfaction with the governance system.
The Governance Committee, chaired by Dr. Woodford Howard, is presently charged only with determining
whether "widespread dissatisfaction"
exists with the system. If it finds such
dissatisfaction, it will be up to a second
committee to recommend changes.
Guess proposed that this two-step
process be condensed into one. He
claimed that the duly elected represen-

tatives of both undergraduate and graduate students bad already expressed
great dissatisfaction with the governance process, thus making the Howard
Committee's task somewhat unnecessary.

Galvanize Forces
Stating that "most representatives
in the governance system feel that just
to identify the problem is not enough,"
Guess hopes to "galvanize forces to
get a special Faculty General Assembly meeting called, because it's the
only way to get the committee recharged."
Guess also suggested that since the
Committee had done all the preliminary work in investigating the issue, it
should also complete the investigation.
"Given the wealth of information before the Committee, they should be the
ones to try to find answers," commented Guess.
Guess claimed that he had tried to
set up an official meeting with the Faculty General Assembly through Dr.
Michael Beer, its Vice-Cha'rman, in
late February. Such a meeting was
actually planned, said Guess, but was
subsequently cancelled by Beer.
In response, Beer stated that he
had originally consented to such a meeting. He later discovered, however,that
Guess had not consulted the Howard
committee about the proposed meeting. After telling Guess to talk to the
Committee about it, Beer said that he
had heard no more.
Disagreeing with Guess, Beer felt
that "it isn't clear" that governance
"Is a burning issue in the minds of
students." He intimated that he was
totally satisfied with the progress of
the Governance Committee,stating that
"things are moving along at as healthy
a pace as can be expected."
Beer also disagreed with Guess'
claims that the two-step, two-committee investigation of the governance
was time-consuming. Remarked Beer,
"I think that these issues are important enough to be considered carefully."

University governance.
Eight of the revision's twelve points
deal with the SAC's recommendations for
the formation of the proposed University
Senate, and, in general, they provide
methods of getting the Senate into operation as quickly as possible.
The remaining four segments relate
the SAC's opinions on the desirability

opinion of the Committee was that Dr.

approval. Over the intersession, he recruited six people who would be interested in taking the class, though,

William Benzon's argument in

he can't be sure of this, and the
fact that the hearing was closed
prohibits a direct refutation of
this claim. However, Benzon appears to base his agrument on his

to counter two particulars in his

In 1876, Daniel Colt Gilman had an idea. Ninety-four

Student-run seminar courses that are conducted with

approval. Over the intersession, he recruited six people who would be interested in taking the class, though,
since then, the number has swelled to twelve.

Two Papers
O'Dell gave six introductory lectures and reading assignments on Jung. Students were obliged to do two

therapists on the East Coast and no funds are accessible
to pay their high fees.

aren't done, credit will not be given.

seminar room in Ames Hall. No faculty members are

fights."

the theories of Carl Jung.

"I don't have teaching skills. But I think that I get

Hampton House: Disapointment, Disgust, Apathy
The following article was written by Nannette Woolcock
from the Hopkins Nursing School (Hampton House).
Although the story was edited, its content remains
unchanged.
Disappointment, disgust, misunderstanding,low morale
and apathy seem to describe the atmosphere surrounding
the students of the Hopkins School of Nursing. With emotions at a peak, most students have decided that some sort
of action must be taken with regard to their lack of communication with the administration.
The crisis has culminated in the refusal of the executivefaculty committee to grant the students' request for a fourday weekend at Easter. In January the students petitioned
for an extra day and supported this demand by what they
considered reasonable arguments.
At the time other requests were made concerning graduation and the dress code. Only the dress code changes requested by the students were accepted. No official notification was given to the student body concerning the request
.for an extended holiday.
According to one instructor, the freshman class has
"reacted in an abnormal way to stress." The class of '72
has already received more social regulation changes and
has apparently demanded more personalized attention than
have previous classes.
Facts indicating student inability to cope with
the
anxiety-producing situations peculiar to a nursing
education are: approximately 70 percent of the class
of '69
sought Psychiatric Counceling, according to one
instructor; the class of '70, once 83 in number, is now
hoping to
graduate 49;the junior class,once 81 strong,has diminished to 50.

To many students the controversy over the four-day
weekend symbolizes the underlying discontent of the student body, and its feeling that communication with the
administration is lacking. This idea is embodied in a second petition, to be submitted for consideration.Some students, particularly juniors, feel the need to go directly
to Mrs. Price, the Director of Nursing,and express their
disappointment and hopes that satisfactory action can be
taken.
The reasons behind the students' continued appeal are:
they are tired; the extra day is of no academic signifigance
since grades will be handed in by March 24; four days
would make traveling much less strenuous; it is a religious
holiday for a majority of the students; and it is the end of a
semester. Some administratorsfind these reasons unconvincing. As one has remarked, "You knew nursing was
going to be tough when you came. If you can't take it,
leave."
The students have voiced reactions against such attitudes. One student, Michele Cawley, stated, "We should be
treated as individuals and can no longer tolerate being
victims of an impenetrable system." A senior student
mentioned the fact that "We're tired of swallowing everything, and we're ready to vomit."
At one point there had been discussion by a number of
angry students over the possibility of not showing up for
work on March 26, after proper notification of the clinical
areas involved. Other students were finally roused to
meet and discuss other less dramatic but equally effective
ways to express their dissatisfaction. Plans for immediate establishment of better and more mature lines of
communication are underway.
